thread.title: Nonprofit takes veterans from Savannah to Washington to see national monuments
thread.title_full: Nonprofit takes veterans from Savannah to Washington to see national monuments | savannahnow.com

author: Dash Coleman
title: Nonprofit takes veterans from Savannah to Washington to see national monuments
text:
Photos Back | Next Patriot Guard motorcyclists prepare to escort an Honor Flight Savannah charter bus full of veterans from Hunter Army Airfield to Interstate 16 as it embarks on a trip to Washington, D.C., to allow veterans to visit national war monuments for free. (Dash Coleman/Savannah Morning News) Back | Next Photos by Dash Coleman/Savannah Morning News
Above, Korean War veteran John Phillips is saluted by active-duty members of the military Friday morning at Hunter Army Airfield as he and other veterans walk toward an Honor Flight Savannah charter bus bound for Washington, D.C. Below, active-duty service members from all branches of the U.S. military salute 22 veterans of World War II and the Korean and Vietnam wars Friday morning as the veterans walk down a painted “red carpet” toward an Honor Flight Savannah charter bus taking them to Washington, D.C., to visit national war monuments.
Back | Next Active-duty service members from all branches of the U.S. military salute 22 veterans of World War II and the Korean and Vietnam wars Friday morning at Hunter Army Airfield as the veterans walk down a painted “red carpet” toward an Honor Flight Savannah charter bus taking them to Washington, D.C., to visit national war monuments. (Dash Coleman/Savannah Morning News)
Back | Next Dash Coleman/Savannah Morning News
Korean War veteran Frank Grady Jr. boards an Honor Flight Savannah tour bus bound for Washington, D.C., on Friday.
By Dash Coleman J ohn Phillips was flanked by saluting members of each U.S. military branch Friday morning as he walked across a faux red carpet toward a waiting charter bus at Hunter Army Airfield.
So were the other 22 veterans taking a free ride to Washington, D.C., to tour the national war monuments dedicated to their service and the lives lost in conflicts across the world.
“It would never occur to me when I was coming up that something like this would happen,” said Phillips, a Korean War veteran who served as an airman in both the Army and the Air Force and recently moved here from Denver. “So many of us go through regular life and never get recognition for just being here, so this is mind boggling for me.”
The trips are something Honor Flight does regularly. The national nonprofit hauls veterans to see the monuments for free. Most of them fly, but the Savannah chapter takes a charter bus for a two-night trip.
“When the veterans get there, the emotions — you can read it in their faces,” said Suzi Oliver, vice chairwoman of the Savannah chapter’s board.
“Sometimes there are tears... When they get to these memorials and they’re with fellow veterans, the stories — sometimes you can see the pain in their eyes. It’s really incredible.”
Initially, the organization only flew veterans of World War II and expanded to include veterans of the Korean War. The Savannah chapter has started to include Vietnam War veterans, three of whom left on the bus Friday morning. Each veteran is teamed up with a personal “guardian” — or chaperone, and nurses and a doctor accompany the group on trips.
The free trip’s only good once. But that doesn’t stop some repeat veterans.
Frank Grady Jr. is one of them. The Sun City, S.C., veteran of the Korean War paid his own way Friday to serve as one of the guardians — he took the free trip in May.
“You don’t know what to expect, and they just overwhelm you,” said Grady, 84.
The veterans had a mission, too.
After some new Army recruits recited the oath of enlistment, the veterans were asked to stand.
Lt. Col. Michael Squires, the garrison commander at Hunter, told them to report to “active duty” for the purpose of taking the trip to Washington.
